column4: we mostly use the american system, but traditionally 10^12 is a billion, 10^9 is a thousand million and 10^6 is a million.  no milliard anywhere

if you want a take a screenshot without user interaction: "import -window root /tmp/screen.png" will do it.  it's in the 'imagemagick' package.
don't use -O if you're using -P

install flashplayer-mozilla as well

great
what's that?
is 1.5 patched against it?
I don't know of a utility, but you can expand the .deb files and compare the contents.
use "ar xf <file.deb>" to get two .tgz files, and 'tar xf' to expand them
hrmm I meant like if I had libflashplayer.so and wanted to change the second byte to 7 instead of 3 or something
basically automating what would be done in a hex editor
got a minute or two?
sure
sorry.  what did you want to do?
you want to script the editing of a binary file?
basically I can go into a hex editor and edit the nth byte to whatever value I want.  I was wondering if there was a command line utility.
yeah, I guess I could do it in perl or some other language but I thought there may be something like sed for it
it would be easy enough to do with a python script
k thanks
like this: echo 'abcdef' > file.txt; python -c "f = open('file.txt', 'r+'); f.seek(3); f.write('z')"; cat file.txt
ah thanks! you didn't have to, I would have looked it up :)
it's ok.  helps me remember it too :)
if you want to specify the byte in hex: echo 'abcdef' > file.txt; python -c "f = file('file.txt', 'r+'); f.seek(3); f.write('%c' % 0x41)"; cat file.txt

.bashrc

~/.bashrc

if you say "tar xf file.tar a b c" it will only extract a, b and c from file.tar.  the a, b and c arguments refer to contents of file.tar - they aren't treated as tarfiles themselves

yes, but you run the risk of having an app writing to config files in your $HOME as root and changing ownership (seems to happen with k3b for example)
like some of those .Xauthority ownership problems we see sometimes are most likely due to something like that
